column1: Christmas Cookies
Germs : Biological Weapons and America's Secret War
column8: Deadly germs sprayed in shopping malls
column9: bomb-lets spewing anthrax spores over battlefields
column10: tiny vials of plague scattered in Times Square -- these are the poor man's hydrogen bombs
column11: hideous weapons of mass destruction that can be made in a simple laboratory. In this groundbreaking work of investigative journalism
column14: and William Broad of The New York Times uncover the truth about biological weapons and show why bio-warfare and bio-terrorism are fast becoming our worst national nightmare.  Among the startling revelations in Germs:   How the CIA secretly built and tested a model of a Soviet-designed germ bomb
column15: alarming some officials who felt the work pushed to the limits of what is permitted by the global treaty banning germ arms. How the Pentagon embarked on a secret effort to make a superbug. Details about the Soviet Union's massive hidden program to produce biological weapons
column16: including new charges that germs were tested on humans. How Moscow's scientists made an untraceable germ that instructs the body to destroy itself. The Pentagon's chaotic efforts to improvise defenses against Iraq's biological weapons during the 1991 Persian Gulf War. How a religious cult in Oregon in the 1980s sickened hundreds of Americans in a bio-terrorism attack that the government played down to avoid panic and copycat strikes. Plans by the U.S. military in the 1960s to attack Cuba with germ weapons.   Germs also shows how a small group of scientists and senior officials persuaded President Bill Clinton to launch a controversial multibillion-dollar program to detect a germ attack on U.S. soil and to aid its victims -- a program that
column18: is struggling to provide real protection.  Based on hundreds of interviews with scientists and senior officials
column20: as well as on recently declassified documents and on-site reporting from the former Soviet Union's sinister bio-weapons labs
column21: Germs shows us bio-warriors past and present at work at their trade. There is the American scientist who devoted his professional life to perfecting biological weapons
column22: and the Nobel laureate who helped pioneer the new biology of genetically modified germs and is now trying to stop its misuse. We meet former Soviet scientists who made enough plague
column24: and anthrax to kill everyone on Earth and whose expertise is now in great demand by terrorists
column26: and legitimate research labs alike.  A frightening and unforgettable narrative of cutting-edge science and spycraft
column27: Germs shows us why advances in biology and the spread of germ weapons expertise to such countries as Iran
column29: and North Korea could make germs the weapon of the twenty-first century.

column1: All over but the Shoutin'
column3: A New York Times Notable Book of the YearThis haunting
column6: gloriously moving recollection of a life on the American margin is the story of Rick Bragg
column7: who grew up dirt-poor in northeastern Alabama
column8: seemingly destined for either the cotton mills or the penitentiary
column9: and instead became a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for The New York Times. It is the story of Bragg's father
column10: a hard-drinking man with a murderous temper and the habit of running out on the people who needed him most.But at the center of this soaring memoir is Bragg's mother
column11: who went eighteen years without a new dress so that her sons could have school clothes and picked other people's cotton so that her children wouldn't have to live on welfare alone. Evoking these lives--and the country that shaped and nourished them--with artistry
column14: Rick Bragg brings home the love and suffering that lie at the heart of every family. The result is unforgettable.

column1: Oilers and Sweepers and Other Stories
Prince William
The Emperor's New Mind
Hill Rat: Blowing the Lid Off Congress
column3: As a top aide to powerful Texas Congressman Ronald Coleman
column5: John Jackley watched the nation's highest elected officials lie
column7: and spend millions of taxpayer dollars to stay in power. The mind-boggling scope of the abuse of perks and privilege by both legislators and their staffers finally shocked him into reality.What began as a secret journal for his children to clear his conscience has become Hill Rat
column8: a journey behind Congress' closed doors and into the corrupt back alleys of power. With both humor and outrage
column9: Jackley reveals how the promise of Congress has been hijacked and corrupted by the current crop of careerist incumbents. Today
column11: a successful congressman has the fundraising ability of a hooker trying to make cab fare home and the morals of a big-time football coach!His account is laced with the names of Capitol Hill's most prominent legislators--Majority Leader Richard Gephardt
column12: Speaker of the House Thomas Foley
column17: and scores of others. Jackley also reveals
column21: the outrageous power of Congressional staffers--Hill Rats--who run the engines of democracy on a daily basis and pride themselves on their ability to do anything in the name of their cause.To show the flagrant abuse of taxpayers' money for re-election purposes
column22: Jackley points out that in just forty-eight hours in early 1992
column23: the House mailed more than 58 million newsletters and postcards. In 1990
column26: 96% of the incumbents who ran were reelected. Even in 1988
column27: only six Members running for re-election were defeated
column28: a turnover rate less than that of the Soviet Politburo.From previously untold Congressional involvement in Oliver North's contra re-supply network to Democratic complicity in the S&L crisis to the taxpayer-funded incumbent protection plan
column29: Hill Rat reveals secrets backed by hard evidence that will shake the House and shock the nation.

column1: Shadow Song
column6: the kind of love everybody ought to have. It changed my life - or almost did - and I think about it more than I should
column7: but that was a long time ago.Amid the breathtaking beauty of the Catskill Mountains
column8: Avrum Feldman listened to the haunting voice of Amelita Galli-Curci ringing over the Shandaken Valley - a voice no one else could hear. When he died at age one hundred six
column9: his obsession for the famous opera diva had lasted three-quarters of a century. Most people considered Avrum crazy
column10: someone preoccupied with romantic nonsense. But Madison Lee Bobo Murphy was not among them
column13: had a love that changed his life
column14: or almost did: Amy Lourie.In the summer of 1955
column15: Bobo was a waiter at the Catskill's Pine Hill Inn; a rural Southerner who had never heard the word meshugge until Avrum - a retired furrier
column17: and translator from New York City - became his unlikely friend. For Bobo nothing about that summer ever lost its glow: his first taste of kartoffel suppe; the exotic mingling of Yiddish and German in the dining room; the girl he met and loved....In everyone's life
column20: undeniable moment of change that never stops mattering. It came for Bobo in his first meeting with Amy
column21: the most beautiful girl he had ever seen. He was too naive to comprehend the gulf between their worlds
column22: and she was too smitten by him to care. But for a wealthy Jewish girl and a Georgia farm boy
column24: leaving Bobo to learn the painful lesson of loving someone and believing you cannot be with them.Now
column27: leaving a will that beckons Bobo north to the Catskills once more. In the places he'd walked so often on the paths of memory
column28: he embraces the ghosts of old friendships and the haunting hints of Amy's presence
column29: until she unexpectedly appears. Nothing has dimmed the passion of their youth
column30: yet two lifetimes and a thousand Catskills sunsets stand between who they were and who they have become. The strikes against them are different now
column33: as Bobo carries out Avrum's last wishes for a strange Kaddish
column34: he hears the dreams of his youth
column35: of the young man who went forth and became part of a love larger than himself....

column1: Undercurrents: A Therapist's Reckoning With Her Own Depression
The Road Less Traveled and Beyond: Spiritual Growth in an Age of Anxiety
The Kiss: A Memoir
Codebreakers' Victory: How the Allied Cryptogaphers Won World War II
column5: veteran World War II cryptographer Hervie Haufler details how American and British codebreakers were the decisive factor in the Allied victory. From the Purple Machine to the Navajo Talkers to the breaking of Japan's JN-25 Naval Code to the shadowy world of decoding units like Hut-8 in Bletchley Park
column6: he shows how crucial information-often obtained by surreptitious and violent means-was the decisive edge in the Battle of Britain
column7: at Midway and against the U-Boats in the North Atlantic
column8: and how Allied intelligence saved the Soviet Union from almost certain defeat.  In an accessible account based on years of research
column9: interviews and exclusive access to previously top-secret archives
column10: Haufler demonstrates how cryptography enabled Nimitz and MacArthur to persevere in the Pacific and helped Eisenhower and Patton mount the assaults on Normandy. In compelling detail
column11: Haufler shows us how it was done-as only one who was on the frontlines of the secret war could tell it.

column9: the Best New American Voices series has been acclaimed for the range and originality of its selections
column10: which represent the writers who promise to become the literary stars of tomorrow. The 2003 collection continues the tradition

column1: Escape from the CIA: How the CIA Won and Lost the Most Important KGB Spy Ever to Defect to the U.S.
Meditations: On the Monk Who Dwells in Daily Life
column3: Sometimes in their chanting monks will land upon a note and sing it in florid fashion
column5: one syllable of text for fifty notes of chant. Melisma
column6: they call it.Living a melismatic life in imitation of plainchant
column7: we may stop on an experience
column10: or a memory and rhapsodize in imagination. Some like to meditate or contemplate melismatically
column14: or dance whatever their eye has fallen upon.Living one point after another
column16: and it can be emphatically productive. But stopping for melisma gives the soul its reason for being.
